quote.para: (1) (a)The issue of the fatality on board the Glory Cape on 1 November 1995 was the subject of a finding by the District Coroner at Port Hedland on 7 May 1997. A copy of this finding has been provided to the Table Office.

(b) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) advised the Panamanian maritime administration of the incident. However, AMSA has been unable to determine what actions the Panamanian authorities have taken in response to their representation.

(2) The circumstances surrounding the incident on the Glory Cape were considered by the Western Australian State Police in preparing their report for the Coroner. In addition, the issues which fell within AMSA's safety jurisdiction were addressed as part of the normal port State control process. The Panamanian maritime administration was advised of the incident involving the vessel. The recent Ship Safe Report highlighted this incident and the Government has accepted a recommendation for further action.

(3) It is reported that in April 1997, the vessel was sold to Greek interests and later, in August that year, the vessel was renamed the SD Glory under Panamanian registry. Information available to AMSA indicates that under the name of Glory Cape, the vessel did not return to Australia following the incident at Dampier in November 1995. However, following the change of name in mid-1997, it has been reported that the vessel made three calls at Australia to pick up cargoes of coal, sugar and grain.

subdebateinfo.title: International Transfer of Prisoners Act: Western Australian Legislation Delay
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1079)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 7 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say what is the cause of the delay in WA enacting legislation complementary to the International Transfer of Prisoners Act which would allow it to participate in the scheme.
(2) When does he expect WA to pass the complementary legislation.
(3) How quickly could Australia enter into an international agreement with the US to enable the transfer of prisoners between both countries, once domestic legislation is in place.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) I am advised that the delay in the WA Government introducing complementary legislation on this matter has been due to two main factors the need to resolve with the WA Government important issues relating to the administration of the transfer scheme and the other competing legislative priorities of the WA Government. I am advised that the issues relating to the administration of the scheme were satisfactorily resolved and a bill was introduced into the WA Parliament on 17 June 1999. However, due to the proroguing of the WA Parliament at the end of the Autumn Session that year, the bill lapsed and was re-introduced on 14 September 1999.
(2) I am advised that the WA Parliament is expected to pass the bill during its Autumn Session this year.

(3) I am advised that it is not possible to provide a firm timetable regarding the entry into force of international agreements under the scheme, as the Commonwealth will need to finalise administrative arrangements with the participating States and Territories once all of the domestic legislation is in place. With respect to transfers between Australia and the US, the Government proposes to seek to accede to the Council of Europe Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons, to which the US is already a party. The Government hopes that transfers pursuant to this agreement will commence this year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 December 1999:

quote.para: Since the conclusion of the waterfront dispute is he able to say whether the Chairman of Lang Corporation or Patrick Stevedores has made comments relating to the cost to importers and exporters of importing or exporting goods. If so (a) do the statement relate to prices for Australian importers and exporters and (b) what are the prices.

Has the Government made approaches to Patrick Stevedores or Lang Corporation about the need to pass on the benefits of the increased productivity, particularly the higher crane rate lift, to Australian importers and exporters.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Evidence given to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee by the Chairman of Patrick Stevedores, Mr Corrigon on 27 August 1999 related in part to charges for stevedoring services.
Mr Corrigon stated stevedoring charges are less than 50% in real terms of what they were 12 years ago.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) also found that while there have not been significant reductions in stevedoring charges, the current level of charges are similar to levels achieved during a stevedoring price war in 1996. This represents a continuing and significant cost saving to shipping lines that, in turn, contributes to lower freight charges for Australia's international trade.

Mr Corrigon gave no specific information relating to stevedoring charges and stated the Government did not ask for specific undertakings in relation to future stevedoring charges. Mr Corrigon stated charges for services are a matter of commercial negotiations between the respective parties.

Patrick and P&O Ports, the two major stevedores, have both committed to the Government's benchmarking objectives for waterfront reform. They were not asked to provide specific undertakings in relation to future stevedoring charges other than a commitment not to pass on the current levy which will repay the funds provided by Government to ensure all stevedoring employees made redundant as part of the reform process received full redundancy requirements. The latest report from the ACCC states the stevedoring company's are absorbing this levy.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) When will the Government make a decision on whether or not a second Sydney airport will be constructed at Badgerys Creek.

(2) What consideration has the Government given to the concerns of western Sydney residents regarding (a) potential aircraft noise impacts, (b) air quality impacts in regard to community health, (c) water quality and (d) lifestyle change.
(3) What consideration has the Government given to the close location of the airport to Warragamba Dam, a major water supply to the Sydney area.
(4) Has the Government given further consideration to building a second airport outside the Sydney basin; if not, why not.
(5) Has the Government considered the proposal of a high speed train linking Sydney with an airport outside the overcrowded Sydney basin; in not, why not.
(6) Has a cost benefit study been undertaken into the Badgerys Creek proposal.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government is actively considering how best to meet Sydney's future airport needs.

(2) Aircraft noise, air quality, water quality, lifestyle change and a wide range of other potential environmental impacts were addressed in the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) prepared for the second Sydney airport proposal. The Final EIS, which was released on 30 June 1999, took into account the issues raised in the submissions on the Draft EIS and the comments from the independent auditor.

In a statement on 3 September 1999, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator the Hon Robert Hill, indicated that the EIS was the most rigorous and comprehensive in Australia's history. His review of the EIS found no insurmountable environmental issue that would prevent the project proceeding, although the cumulative impacts of the proposal would require careful environmental management. Senator Hill also made a number of recommendations to ensure that the environmental management regime would be consistent with worlds best practice. These recommendations are under consideration.
(3) The possible hazards and risks to the Warragamba Dam from aircraft using an airport at Badgerys Creek were specifically addressed in the EIS.
(4) The EIS discussed suggested alternative sites for a second airport both inside and outside the Sydney basin.
(5) The EIS discussed the feasibility of servicing an airport outside the Sydney basin with a high speed train.
(6) A detailed benefit cost analysis of the Badgerys Creek proposal was included in the EIS Supplement published in June 1999

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 7 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) What sum has the Government allocated to each community based child care centre in the electoral division of Prospect in 1999-2000.
(2) Is this level of funding a decrease or an increase on previous years' funding for each centre.
(3) What will be the level of funding for each child care centre in the electoral division of Prospect in 2000-01.
(4) According to current needs based planning, which suburbs in western Sydney have the greatest need for child care facilities.
(5) In which suburbs of Sydney has there been the highest rate of growth in the child care sector.

(7) Will the Minister extend needs based planning controls after the current allocation period finishes on 31 December 1999; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (2) (3) (5) and (6) The detailed information required to answer the honourable member's question is not readily available in a consolidated form. To collect and assemble such information solely for the purpose of answering the honourable member's question would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved.

(4) According to the latest high need area determination (July 1999) which determines the type of care required by location, the suburbs in western Sydney that have been identified as requiring additional care are:
. Parramatta - for centre based long day care, baby care only (0 - 18 months old);
. Baulkham Hills - for Before & After School Hours Care and Vacation Care only.

(7) I have not sought to extend the legislation limiting new centre based long day care places that expired on 31 December 1999. It was not extended because the limit of 7,000 places was not met in either year of the supply limit period. With demand being well met in many areas, growth in new places is expected to be steady over the next few years. The Government is keen to ensure that new growth is well targeted and therefore will be working closely with local government and other key sectors to encourage the establishment of services only in areas of high need. We are closely monitoring trends in the sector and if necessary have the capacity under the family assistance legislation, currently before Parliament, to reintroduce a supply limit for long day care centres. subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan, Mode 8 Implementation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1087)

(3) Will he arrange for an independent safety audit to be undertaken of the effectiveness of any replacement software.
(4) What are the complexities involving Mode 8 which were identified in the draft Long Term Operating Plan and what has the Government done to address or overcome those complexities.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am advised that Mode 8 of the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) at Sydney Kingsford Smith Airport is available for implementation.

(2) Airservices Australia advises that implementation of Mode 8 of LTOP was delayed in order to upgrade the Surface Movement Radar to display changes to the aerodrome layout resulting from extensive taxiway work undertaken by Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 8 December 1999:

quote.para: Was the issue of microeconomic reform one of the Government's reasons for its involvement with the Patrick Stevedores vs MUA dispute. If so, was one aspect of microeconomic reform the lowering of costs to importers and exporters via a greater per hour crane life at Melbourne and other Australian ports.
What was the price of loading (a) full, (b) half and (c) quarter container with Patrick Stevedores (i) prior to the Patrick MUA dispute and (ii) on 8 December 1999.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Government's objective for waterfront reform is to boost productivity, lower costs, improve reliability, emphasise skills and training, and introduce an effective occupational health and safety regime. The approach taken by Government in conjunction with the stevedores has set in train a durable reform process predicated on the notion of continuous improvement that will lead to Australia finally having a reliable, efficient and world class waterfront.

Because of their commercial value the details of contractual arrangements between the stevedores and their customers are not released. However, as part of the monitoring associated with the Government's waterfront reform package the Treasurer has directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to monitor prices, costs and profits relating to the supply of container terminal stevedoring services in a number of ports. The aim being to provide information about the progress of waterfront reform at the terminals and on whether the stevedores have absorbed the cost of the current levy. The ACCC has released its first report covering the period February 1999 to June 1999. The report states that the stevedores have absorbed the cost of the levy. It also contains a general analysis of the structure of the stevedoring industry and historical trends in stevedoring charges.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 8 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Is it a fact that (a) Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (KSA) serves 53 international, national and regional carriers, (b) KSA handles 45% of Australia's total flights, or 275 000 aircraft movements a year, yet it occupies the smallest piece of land of any of the country's major airports and (c) in terms of commercial aviation movements, KSA is an Asia Pacific leader and that KSA ranks comparably with New York's LaGuardia and JFK airports, and well ahead of Singapore's Changi airport and Tokyo's Haneda airport.
(2) Has his attention been drawnto claims by Qantas pilots that KSA is the most disorganised airport in their network.
(3) Is he concerned by the pilots' concerns and what steps will he take to ensure that the pilots' concerns are addressed.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) At 30 June 1999, Sydney KSA was served by a total of 53 carriers, including 38 international scheduled airlines (including 6 cargo airlines and excluding codeshare services). There were also 2 domestic airlines (Ansett and Qantas) and 13 regional airlines operating scheduled services at the airport.

(1) (b) Sydney KSA handled an estimated 249,750 scheduled airline aircraft movements in the 1998/99 year, accounting for 43.7% of Australia's scheduled international airline aircraft movements, 21.9% of domestic airline aircraft movements (Ansett and Qantas) and an estimated 14.3% of regional airline aircraft movements. Fixed wing aircraft activity at Sydney KSA amounted to some 273,644 aircraft movements in the 1998/99 year.

Sydney KSA occupies a land area of 881 hectares, while the newer Melbourne Tullamarine airport has an area of 2,365 hectares, Brisbane airport covers 2,685 hectares and Australia's fourth major airport, Perth airport is 2,110 hectares in area. Australia's other major airports include Adelaide airport with an area of 762 hectares and Hobart airport with 499 hectares while Darwin airport is situated on 306 hectares.

(1) (c) According to the Airports Council International's annual worldwide traffic report for 1998, Sydney KSA, with a total of 279,152 aircraft movements (including helicopter movements), ranked as the world's 49th busiest airport. New York's JFK airport ranked 35th with 362,182 aircraft movements and New York's La Guardia airport ranked 36th with 358,045 aircraft movements in 1998.

The highest ranked Asian airport was Tokyo's Haneda airport with 236,695 aircraft movements (ranked 68th). Bangkok airport in Thailand ranked 98th with 178,458 aircraft movements and Singapore's Changi airport ranked 100th with 177,372 aircraft movements in 1998.

The United States of America (USA) remains the world's leading aviation market with 39 of the top 50 ranked airports. The 451,373 aircraft movements at London's Heathrow airport ranked that airport at number 17, the highest ranked non-USA airport.
No.

subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Air Safety Investigation: Crosswinds
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1096)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 8 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Has the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) claimed that noise sharing policies have forced aircraft to land outside International Civil Aviation Organisation standards, which stipulate that landing aircraft operate within a maximum of 15kt. crosswinds and 5 kt. tailwind.

(2) Has a BASI investigation found that aircraft have been requested to land with crosswinds of up to 25 kt., concluding that the landings produced the undesirable effects of reduced safety margins and increased complexity of the surrounding airspace.
(3) Have there been international incidents in the last 3 years, when aircraft have been forced off a runway by crosswinds in excess of 15 kt; if so what were the circumstances of those incidents.
(4) Is it Government policy that safety should prevail over noise sharing modes of operation; if so what steps has he taken to ensure that safety considerations are given that priority.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. In the BASI Air Safety Report Systemic Investigation into Factors Underlying Air Safety Occurrences in Sydney Terminal Area Airspace, Section 1.10 Operators states:

“Operators of high-capacity aircraft were concerned about the crosswind component of 25 kts that was acceptable for the continued use of runway modes at Sydney. The `close-set' parallel runways 16/34 and the short length of 25/07 and 34R/16L, were cited as the reason for this concern. Whilst most agreed that it was within the crosswind capability of both the aircraft and the flight crews to use these runways in significant crosswind, there was general agreement that it had served to erode the safety margin. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has recommended that compliance with published noise abatement procedures should not be required in `adverse operating conditions' such as when `the crosswind component, including gusts, exceeds 15 kts'. It was reported that the International Federation of Airline Pilots Association (IFALPA) has recently `black banned' the Amsterdam airport following an accident in which a Boeing 757 veered off the runway whilst the flight crew was attempting to land the aircraft in similar crosswind conditions. Amsterdam airport has similar noise-sharing requirements and crosswind policies to Sydney.”

The Bureau also noted that the Australian Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) Sydney noise abatement procedures allow for the continued use of dry runways with a crosswind component of up to 25 kts and a downwind component of up to 5 kts. Continued use of wet runways is permissible with a crosswind component of up to 25 kts with no downwind component, or a crosswind of up to 15 kts with a downwind component of up to 5 kts.
(2) The BASI Air Safety Report Systemic Investigation into Factors Underlying Air Safety Occurrences in Sydney Terminal Area Airspace, Section 3.0 Findings states:

“The current policy of operating the short runways at Sydney with up to 25 kts of crosswind has reduced safety margins for arriving and departing aircraft and has increased the complexity of the surrounding airspace when some aircraft operationally require alternative runway for arrival or departure.”
As a consequence of this finding, BASI issued Recommendation R980164.

“Airservices Australia, in conjunction with the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, reconsider the current policy of routinely operating the short runways at Sydney with up to 25 kts crosswind when other runway options are available.”

In response CASA undertook a review of the 25 knots crosswind criteria and this review involved consultations with Airservices, the aviation industry and the pilots' associations. Following that review CASA indicated that it considered that the practice of routinely operating runways with up 25 knots of crosswind before initiating a change of nominated runway does not pose an unacceptable safety hazard.
(3) Yes. The Bureau is currently aware of one incident - please refer to the answer to Question 1.

(4) Yes. In establishing the noise sharing arrangements at Sydney Airport under the Airport's Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon John Sharp, formally directed Airservices Australia to undertake formal safety analyses of the operational components of the Plan prior to their implementation. Airservices Australia advises that a safety case was undertaken for each stage of LTOP implementation. The safety cases found that the various procedures to implement LTOP were safe to introduce and implementation was conditional on safety requirements identified in the safety cases being in place.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 8 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims made by the Air Traffic Controllers union that all the attention on noise has made Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (KSA) dangerous and that landing conditions at Sydney are ludicrous.
(2) What steps will he take to address those concerns.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) Safety factors have been the overriding consideration in establishing the noise sharing regime at Sydney Airport. In establishing these arrangements under the Sydney Airport Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon John Sharp, directed Airservices Australia to undertake formal safety analyses of the operational components of the Plan prior to their implementation. Airservices Australia advises that a safety case was undertaken for each phase of LTOP implementation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) How many subclass 676 visitor visa applications were made in (a) Pakistan, (b) the UK and (c) the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in each year over the period 1995 to 1999.
(2) How many subclass 676 visitor visa applications were rejected each year over the period 1995 to 1999 from (a) Pakistan, (b) the UK and (c) the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

(4) How many subclass 676 visitor visa applications were rejected on the third application each year over the period 1995 to 1999 from (a) Pakistan, (b) the UK and (c) the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) It is not possible to provide all of the historical data that the honourable member has requested as prior to November 1998 only information on visa grants was sent from overseas posts to the Department's Central Office in Canberra. The number of applications made by citizens of FYROM prior to November 1998 is not available. I can say, however, that during the years 1995/96, 1996/97 and 1997/98 the number of visitor visa applications made by all nationalities in Pakistan and the United Kingdom were as follows:

The number of applications made at Australian posts from 1 November 1998 to 31 November 1999 for citizens of Pakistan, the UK and FYROM were:
Pakistan 5094
FYROM 2273
The majority of visitor visa applications were for 676 short stay visitor visas, however, the figures also include long stay visitor and business visitor visa applications.
(2) The number of applications rejected during the years since 1995/96 are as follows:
Pakistan

Rejections Nov 98 to Nov 99
Pakistan 2688

A higher rejection rate is a consequence of a higher level of scrutiny of applications in high-risk environments. I have instructed Migration Officers overseas and in Australia to ensure that they balance their deliberations between the need for a quick response within the context of available resources, and the need to protect Australia from the possible entry of non bona-fide tourists.

Officers of my Department have for many years accumulated data on the relative risk of visitors remaining in Australia beyond the term of their visitor visa. The Risk Factor, Public interest Criterion 4011, was introduced by the previous Government in the early 1990s.

In the case of Pakistan and FYROM the past actions of their countrymen and women have resulted in the inclusion in the Risk Factor. The Risk Factor schedule includes male Pakistanis 20 to 49 and above 60 and females aged more than 20 and Macedonian males and females aged 20 and above. The visitor non-return rates for these two countries are 41% for FYROM and 14% in Pakistan. You have asked for a comparison with the United Kingdom. The visitor non-return rate for the UK is 1.9%. (3) As each application is considered as a new and separate application, the Department does not keep statistics on the number of subsequent applications. Where later applications are supported by new information that is adequate for the decision-maker to be assured that a genuine visit is intended those applications will be approved.
(4) This question was answered in (3).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1999:

quote.para: What are the specific reasons for him identifying the category of Males 20 to 49 inclusive from (a) Pakistan and (b) the Former Republic of Macedonia as worthy of inclusion as a high risk group as per paragraph 4011(2)(b) of Schedule 4 of the Migration Regulations 1994.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Public Interest Criterion 4011, which is referred to as the “Risk Factor”, includes countries from which there were more than 500 visitor arrivals and have a visitor non-return rate greater than 3 times the global average. In addition to the larger visitor sources, countries from which there have been more than 50 but less than 500 visitors and have a visitor non-return rate greater than 6 times the global average are included. The global average is 2.1%. The Risk Factor is based on data drawn from the 1996/97 year. At the time of review this was the most recent full year available that allowed visitors to complete travel under multiple entry visas.
- The “risk rate” is based on the number of visitor arrivals who have:
- lawfully departed after the expiry date of their visa: or
- departed without a lawful visa; or
- remained in Australia on a further substantive visa after the expiry of their arrival visa; or
- remained in Australia on any class of bridging visa after the expiry of the arrival visa; or
- remained in Australia without a visa.

In order to obtain a visitor visa, applicants are required to present evidence to DIMA decision-makers that they have every intention of departing Australia before the expiry of their visitor visa. The Migration Regulations provide for some visitors to seek an extension of their stay after arrival or to change status to permanent residence. However, when data shows that visitors from certain countries use these provisions at a rate many times the global average, decision-makers must question the evidence supporting the application for a genuine visit.
Referring specifically to the groups that you have mentioned. The non-return rates for Pakistani and Macedonian males aged 20 to 49 are:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Further to his letter to the editor of The Bulletin of 14 December 1999, was his most recent representation to Indonesian General Wiranto about violence in East Timor made on 29 July 1999.

subdebateinfo.title: South African Accountants: Permanent Resident Applications
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1110)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) How many applications for permanent residency were made by accountants from South Africa in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97, (e) 1997-98 and (f) 1998-99.
(2) How many of those applicants were granted permanent residency in each year.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) - (2) While a person with Accountancy skills may enter Australia under any visa subclass, only those entering under the Skilled Stream of the Migration Program are required to have their skills assessed as part of the migration process. The relevant visa subclasses are 105 (Skilled Australian Linked, formerly Concessional Family), 106 (Regional Linked), 121 (Employer Nomination Scheme) and 126 (Independent). Table 1 below gives a summary of the number of South African accountant applications received and processed in Pretoria in each year in the Skilled Stream.
Table 1: Accountant Applications Lodged and Processed
A detailed break down of this, including the relevant visa subclass is at Table 2 below.

Of those cases that were not approved, this does not necessarily mean that they failed to meet the skill level for the occupation of Accountant. There could be a number of reasons for this, including withdrawals or applicants not achieving sufficient points for the age or sponsorship factors.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1999.

quote.para: When skills assessing applicants for permanent residency, are accountant applicants made aware that they are required to meet statutory requirements to (a) work as a company auditor and (b) provide advice on taxation matters; if so, where is this information contained in the Department's procedures advice manuals.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: To be awarded points for the skill factor, applicants must be assessed to have skills (ie qualifications and work experience) equivalent to the “Australian standard”.

In relation to the occupation of Accountant, the required Australian standard for migration purposes was set in consultation with the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR), the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants (ASCPA) and the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Australia (ICAA). All accountant type skills assessment are undertaken by the ASCPA and ICAA, the relevant professional bodies responsible for the recognition of overseas-trained accountants seeking to migrate to Australia.

While there are no legal requirements governing the employment of Accountants in Australia, those who carry out specialised accounting functions (eg company auditors and those who provide advice on taxation matters) are subject to statutory requirements. Generally, all successful applicants are advised to contact the relevant authority in their intended State/Territory of residence for further advice on requirements to practice their profession in the State/Territory.
The information on statutory requirements can be found in sections 2.2 and 4.10 of the Procedure Advice Manual 3 (PAM3) for the occupation of Accountant.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: In order to pass a skills assessment as an accountant (occupational classification ASCO 2701), is an applicant required to meet specified academic and professional standards; if so, do the South African qualifications (a) Bachelor of Commerce (University of Withwaterstrand) and (b) Institute of Commercial and Financial Accountants of Southern Africa meet the NOORSR Country Education Profiles for the Accountants skills assessment.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The current minimum Australian eligibility requirement is an Australian Bachelor degree with a major in Accounting and completion of relevant institute/society examination and experience requirements. These requirements are set out at Section 2.1 of the PAM3 guidelines for Accountants.

In relation to an overseas applicant, s/he must hold an overseas Bachelor degree that is comparable to an Australian Bachelor degree. The overseas qualification must have an accounting major and include adequate coverage of certain accounting subjects. However, in relation to an applicant who did not major in accounting, only the ASCPA or the ICAA have the authority to determine whether s/he meets the Australian standard for an Accountant. In addition, to gain professional membership of either the ASCPA or the ICAA, overseas applicants may be required to study additional subjects in Australia that may include Australian company and taxation law.

A Bachelor of Commerce from the University of Witwatersrand is recognised as comparable to an Australian Bachelor degree under NOOSR's Country Educational Profiles for South Africa. However, as outlined above, possession of a Bachelor's degree is not sufficient to meet Australian standards for the occupation of Accountant.

At present, only professional accountants from any member society of the South African Institute of Chartered Accountants are recognised by the ASCPA and ICAA. In relation to the Institute of Commercial and Financial Accountants of Southern Africa, the standing of this association has not been assessed. It is, therefore, not recognised in Australia at this time.
If a South African applicant holds ICFA membership but does not also hold a comparable Bachelor degree, the applicant will not meet the “Australian standard” for migration purposes as an Accountant.

In the case of an applicant who holds ICFA membership as well as a Bachelor of Commerce from Witwatersrand University or a comparable Bachelor degree, it will not be possible for ASCPA or ICAA to determine whether the applicant will meet the Australian standard without a full skills assessment.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Has he received the final report by the Productivity Commission into the progress of rail reform.
(2) Was the final report received by the due date of 5 August 1999; if not, why not.
(3) When will the final report be tabled or publicly released.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes
(2) Yes

(3) The Government is considering a joint response to the Productivity Commission Report Progress in Rail Reform, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Micro-economic Reform Report Tracking Australia and the Rail Projects Taskforce Report Revitalising Rail. The Productivity Commission Report is expected to be tabled and publicly available during the Autumn Session.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: Are artists entitled to offset the costs of their art practice against other income for income tax purposes; if so, will the implementation of the Ralph report continue this entitlement; if not, what test or tests will the Government apply to determine the eligibility of artists to offset such costs?

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Taxpayers who carry on business as artists are able to offset losses made in the course of carrying on that business as an artist against other income.

The implementation of the Ralph Report will continue this entitlement provided the taxpayer is carrying on business as an artist and satisfies at least one of five tests, which are listed in Attachment A to my Press Release of 11 November 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: What steps will the Government take to ensure that the new electronic three month business visas for overseas performers will not allow producers to sidestep local labour market tests.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: There is no new electronic three month business visa for overseas performers. Business visitors to Australia who wish to stay for up to three months and who have access to the Electronic Travel Authority (ETA), have been able to use the business visitor version of the ETA since 1996. The ETA is provided electronically through a travel agent when airline bookings are made and has dramatically changed the way we deal with legitimate short-term business interests from low immigration risk countries.

The business ETA has been used over the past 3 years by IT contractors, visiting sports teams, overseas media and entertainers. With the Olympics next year, the smooth entry of these people will become even more important. My announcement on 22 October highlighted my intention to issue a Ministerial Direction to provide clearer guidance on the increasingly broad use of the business ETA.

While the ETA has been available since 1996, I am aware of concerns within the entertainment industry regarding use of the business ETA by overseas performers. In response to these concerns, I intend to consider further how these concerns may best be accommodated.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report prepared by Mr Peter Faris QC for the Deputy Director of Prosecutions, which states that Mr Karlis Ozols is the highest ranking alleged war criminal living in Australia and that Mr Ozols and his company have been directly or indirectly involved in the mass murder of thousands of people.

(2) Did he, in March 1997, announce that the Ozols case was closed, even though Mr Faris had advised that there was sufficient evidence to indicate that a prima facie case existed against Mr Ozols for crimes against humanity, for mass murder and for war crimes; if so, why.

(3) Is he able to say whether (a) Mr Faris advised the Deputy Director of Prosecutions that the Ozols case needed a further three months preparation and (b) the Minister for Justice told the ABC 7.30 Report on 6 December 1999 that there was not enough evidence there to proceed.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. I am aware of the report relating to Mr Ozols which was prepared by Mr Peter Faris QC for the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions in June 1992.
(2) I have no record of making such an announcement. The case against Karlis Ozols has not been closed.

The case against him did not proceed because in the Director of Public Prosecution's (DPP) view, the existing material was not sufficient. When the Special Investigation Unit was closed, the Department referred the incomplete case to the Australian Federal Police (AFP), which carried out a review of the investigation, including consultations with the DPP, the War Crimes Prosecution Support Unit and Mr Peter Faris QC, who had provided advice to the DPP in relation to the matter.
The DPP advised that it could not make a final decision on prosecution until further investigations were undertaken.
I am advised by the AFP that in, its professional view, the likelihood of obtaining probative evidence, as a result of those further investigations, was extremely low.
I am advised that the situation was reviewed again by the AFP in 1997 and it was concluded that the likelihood of obtaining probative evidence remained low.

(3) (a) Yes. Mr Faris concluded that further enquiries and investigations were required which he estimated could be completed in three months. However, as noted in (2), there was no guarantee that those investigations would result in material that would be sufficient to lay charges.
(b) The Minister for Justice and Customs stated that the DPP had decided there was not enough evidence to proceed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report prepared by Mr Peter Faris QC for the Deputy Director of Prosecutions, which states that Mr Karlis Ozols is the highest ranking alleged war criminal living in Australia and that Mr Ozols and his company have been directly or indirectly involved in the mass murder of thousands of people.

(2) Is the Minister able to say whether Mr Faris advised that, although only three months more research was required, a prima facie case existed against Mr Ozols for crimes against humanity, for mass murder and for war crimes; if so, why did the case not proceed.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

While a prima facie case existed against Mr Ozols for breaches of Australian war crimes legislation, the evidence did not warrant the laying of charges until further investigations had been conducted. I am advised by the AFP that, in its professional view, the likelihood of obtaining probative evidence, as a result of those further investigations, was extremely low.
The AFP reviewed its earlier decision in 1997, which reaffirmed that a further investigation could not be justified on the information available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 9 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Was the case against Mr Heinrich Wagner, concerning the murder of 19 children in Ukraine, dropped in 1992 because of Mr Wagner's alleged ill-health.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a story on the ABC's 7.30 Report on 6 December 1999 which indicated that Mr Wagner is currently in good health; if so, can the case now proceed; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The prosecution of Mr Wagner was discontinued on 9 December 1993. The decision not to proceed with Mr Wagner's trial in 1993 was based on medical evidence of his then state of health.
(2) My attention has been drawn to the story on Mr Wagner on the ABC's 7.30 Report on 6 December 1999.
I have not been made aware of any medical evidence which contradicts the basis upon which that decision was made or which reveals the current state of Mr Wagner's health.
If evidence is forthcoming that Mr Wagner's health is, indeed, sufficiently improved to withstand the stress of a criminal trial, the question of a prosecution could be reviewed.

The health of the accused would not be the sole consideration in deciding whether to commence a new prosecution. The sufficiency of the available evidence would also need to be reviewed, including the availability of witnesses who may themselves have become ill or died during the period since Mr Wagner's prosecution was discontinued.
